individual_results.base_prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction

Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a  biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter Seven: The Last Harvest**

The air in the underground vault tasted of rust and old ozone. Kael adjusted the cracked lens of his goggles, squinting at the flickering readout on the salvaged PCR machine—a relic from the last days of *Genovate Biotech*, now a rusted skeleton in the corner of the bunker. The machine had once belonged to a failed synthetic wheat project, one of the many experiments designed to make crops "smarter" by overloading their DNA with corporate patents. But those patents had a flaw: built-in obsolescence. Every gene sequence was engineered to degrade after one generation. A plant grown from that DNA would thrive—then vanish after the next season. Genovate called it *adaptive turnover*. They called it profit. We called it suicide.

Kael didn’t care about the corporate logic anymore. He cared about the soil. The children. The thin, brittle stalks of *Zea mays* that still grew in the cracked earth outside the settlement’s perimeter, their leaves curling like old paper in the wind.

Tonight, he had a contract.

A black market deal from the nomads of the Iron Ridge—three vials of *Cucurbita pepo* gene fragments, smuggled from a decommissioned Genovate lab in the Midwest. The vials were sealed in empty canisters from a failed *Growth-Boost* line—plastic with a flaking, greenish patina, once used to store synthetic growth hormones. Now they were repurposed. The canisters were perfect: their thin walls held the cold, their internal baffles could be cut to form makeshift reaction chambers. Kael had learned to use them like vials, like test tubes, like prayers.

He’d spent three nights before this, stitching together a jury-rigged PCR setup from a broken centrifuge, a salvaged thermal cycler, and a solar-powered battery pack that flickered like a dying heartbeat. The machine didn’t work like it used to. It stuttered. The temperature swings were erratic. The reagents—salvaged from a defunct lab’s supply closet—were unstable, some of them already beginning to degrade. But Kael had learned to work with failure. He’d found that the instability sometimes worked in reverse: when the PCR failed, the DNA didn’t just break—it *reorganized*, like a broken circuit finding a new path.

He opened the first canister. The greenish plastic groaned under his fingers. Inside, the liquid shimmered with a faint, sickly luminescence. It wasn’t water. It was *DNA*—but not clean. It was fragmented, degraded, and pulsing with the ghost of a gene sequence meant to enhance nitrogen fixation. The kind that could make crops grow in poor soil, in the dead zones where the world had forgotten how to farm.

“This is the last chance,” Kael muttered, his voice dry from days of breathing recycled air. “If this doesn’t work, we’ll have to go back to root crops. To tubers. To things that don’t remember how to grow.”

He poured the liquid into a cut section of the canister, forming a crude reaction chamber. He added a drop of the old Taq polymerase—salvaged from a defunct PCR kit, its enzymes now sluggish, nearly inert. It had been stored in a freezer that had failed two winters ago. The enzyme had been dead for months. But Kael had found something strange: when exposed to low temperatures and repeated thermal cycling, it *reactivated*. Not fully. But enough.

He set the machine to cycle through 30 rounds of denaturation, annealing, and extension. The screen flickered. The temperature gauge spiked. Then it dipped. Then it exploded into a burst of static.

Kael’s hands trembled. He’d never seen a PCR fail so spectacularly. But as the machine cooled, a faint glow pulsed from the chamber. Not the green of healthy DNA. A deep, pulsing blue—like a dying star.

He wiped his hands on his worn lab coat and reached for the spectrometer, a broken device he’d jury-rigged with a smartphone and a solar-powered sensor. The screen lit up. The results were messy, but there—clear as a crack in the sky—was a new sequence. Not from the original gene. Not from any known plant. A hybrid. A *mutation*.

“It’s working,” he whispered. “It’s *alive*.”

The next morning, the settlement gathered in the central courtyard. Children stood with their hands on the soil, watching as Kael introduced the first batch of spliced seeds—grown from the blue-glowing DNA. The plants were small. Thin. But they grew. They *grew* in the cracked, nutrient-poor ground where nothing had grown in years.

And when the first green shoot broke through, the children laughed. Not because it was perfect. But because it was *different*. It wasn’t a copy. It wasn’t a clone. It was a *new thing*.

That night, Kael sat on the edge of the bunker’s rusted platform, watching the first harvest. He had no idea if the modifications were safe. The DNA was unstable. The enzymes were failing. He had no documentation. No approval. Just a contract from a stranger who didn’t know the cost of genetic failure.

But something unexpected happened.

One of the children, Lira, who had been sick with the chronic fatigue that plagued the settlement, ate a piece of the new squash. She didn’t speak for two days. Then she did. Her voice was soft, but clear. “I feel… lighter,” she said. “Like I’ve been breathing again.”

Kael didn’t know if it was the food. Or the DNA. Or something deeper—something that had been buried in the genes of every living thing since the world stopped caring.

Still, he kept working. The canisters were empty now. He’d used them all. But he’d learned something: in a world built on engineered obsolescence, the only thing that lasted was *adaptation*. Not perfection. Not profit. Just the stubborn, fragile act of *trying*.

He opened a new canister—this one from a different lab, labeled *Project Phoenix*. It was sealed with a yellow sticker, the kind that once said *DO NOT REACTIVATE*. He didn’t read the label. He just cut it open.

And for the first time in months, he smiled.

Because maybe, just maybe, the future wasn’t in the genes. Maybe it was in the cracks. In the failures. In the things we built to break—and then learned to mend.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The piece nails the prompt’s core requirements: a post-collapse biopunk world, jury-rigged lab gear, degrading DNA, a black-market contract, and the physical gamble of self-experimentation. It keeps the camera tight on Kael, shows the settlement’s desperation, and lets the tech feel scavenged rather than showroom-shiny. World-building details—Genovate’s “adaptive turnover,” the repurposed hormone canisters, the half-dead Taq—are concrete and specific.  

Yet the story never rises above functional. Kael is a checklist of stoic-scientist tropes: gaunt, obsessive, mutters to himself, smiles wanly at the end. No contradiction, no memory, no fear that isn’t generic. The black-market contract is mentioned twice but never negotiated, threatened, or jeopardized; it functions as a mere trigger for the night’s work, so the promised plot engine idles. The “unexpected upside” of the squash is delivered in a single, summary paragraph about Lira’s recovery—told, not shown, and not connected to any cost or risk Kael personally suffers. The prose is serviceable but littered with workshop reflexes: em-dashed exposition, italicized buzz-phrases, a final paragraph that gestures toward lyric uplift without earning it. Sentences frequently start with “He” or “The,” creating a plodding cadence that undercuts any tension. Imagery is repeated (cracked earth, flickering screens, rust) until it feels like a mood board rather than a lived place. The ending’s hopeful smile lands as a sentimental overlay because the narrative has never risked anything we’re afraid to lose.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction

Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a  biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter Seven: The Last Splice**

The air in the underground bunker tasted like rust and old antiseptic. Outside, the sky bled violet through the fractured glass of the old biohub—what used to be a corporate research facility, now a graveyard of failed gene splices and abandoned protocols. Inside, the hum of the generator was the only rhythm. A steady, tired pulse, like a failing heart. And in the corner of the lab, a single glow-in-the-dark mushroom pulsed softly beneath a cracked tile, its bioluminescence a ghost of what once was.

Kael wiped sweat from his brow with the back of his hand. His skin was cracked, his fingers raw from handling the salvaged polymerase mix—fragile, unstable, and still active. The last of the viable *Heliothermus* DNA had been pulled from a sealed vial buried beneath a collapsed server rack. It was supposed to last only one generation. But the corporate engineers had built in a flaw: a self-degrading promoter sequence, designed to trigger apoptosis after 300 days. And Kael had managed to extend it. By a few days. Maybe a week. He didn’t know how. He just knew that when he ran the PCR on the soil sample from the northern farm, the reaction had gone green—bright, solid, alive.

“Still not stable,” he muttered, adjusting the makeshift centrifuge. The thing was a repurposed coffee grinder, its blades now coated in rust and biodegradable gel. The temperature control was a jury-rigged thermistor from a dead smartphone, calibrated with a thermocouple salvaged from a dead lab technician’s coat. It flickered. The readings danced. Kael’s eyes narrowed. *Too much variance. Too much decay.*

He’d been working on the black market contract for three days now. A woman named Mira, from the northern settlement, had sent a message through the encrypted mesh: *Need protein-rich greens. Fast. No corporate trace. Will pay in synth-clothing credits and a vial of salvaged insulin.* The insulin was rare—only one vial left in the network. It had been harvested from a dead lab in New Haven, its gene sequence now degraded beyond use, but still functional in emergency cases. Kael had used it to treat a child with a rare metabolic collapse last week. It had worked. The child woke up. Kael hadn’t known if it was the insulin or the stress of the procedure that saved her—but the result was real.

Now, he needed to splice a viable crop. Not just any crop—something that could grow in the acidic soil of the ruins, something that wouldn’t fail after one generation. He had only three viable samples: a modified kale variant with drought tolerance, a root vegetable with enhanced nitrogen fixation, and a spliced fungus that could convert CO₂ into protein. All were one-generation DNA. All were dying.

He pulled the soil sample from the north farm into the PCR chamber. The machine whirred, a sound like a dying engine. The gel tray was homemade—plastic from a defunct water purifier, dyed with indigo from a dead textile plant. The reaction was slow, inconsistent. But when the gel ran, the bands were clearer than expected. A strong, bright band at 150 base pairs. A fainter one at 220. Not full viability. But *potential*.

He didn’t sleep that night. The glow-in-the-dark mushrooms had begun to spread. They’d started as a single spore on a cracked tile near the ventilation shaft. Now they bloomed in clusters, their bioluminescence pulsing in slow waves—like breathing. Kael had seen them before in old lab logs. They were a byproduct of failed splicing experiments, engineered to emit light when their DNA degraded. A warning signal. A biological clock.

He thought about the corporate design. The DNA wasn’t meant to survive. It was meant to *fail*. To create a cycle of dependency—farmers needed new seeds every generation, corporations sold the next batch, and the world kept collapsing. But Kael had seen something else. In the degradation, there was a pattern. A rhythm. The mushrooms didn’t just glow—they *reacted*. When he touched one, the light intensified. When he held it near the PCR chamber, the gel bands shifted. Like the DNA was responding to external stimuli.

He tested it. He placed a live mushroom next to the reaction plate. The PCR output changed. The bands sharpened. The 220-bp signal grew stronger. For the first time in months, the splicing looked stable.

“Not just a failure,” he whispered. “A response.”

The next morning, Mira arrived. She wore a patched-up suit made from recycled polymer, her face lined with exhaustion. She handed over the synth-clothing credits and the vial of insulin. “They say the crops won’t last. That the soil is poisoned. But you’re different. You’re not just splicing. You’re *listening*.”

Kael looked at the mushrooms. They pulsed in time with the generator’s hum.

“Maybe,” he said, “they were never meant to last. Maybe they were meant to *adapt*.”

He took the vial of insulin and placed it beside the PCR plate. Then he added a drop of the fungal extract—the one that had responded to the light. The reaction flared. The gel lit up in a soft blue-green. The bands were clean. Clear. Strong.

He didn’t know if it would grow. He didn’t know if it would survive the next generation. But for the first time, he didn’t feel the dread of failure. He felt something else—a quiet hope.

Later, as he sat in the dim light, the mushrooms began to grow faster. Not just on the tiles. On the walls. On the old lab bench. The glow spread like a slow tide, painting the bunker in shifting patterns of light. It wasn’t beautiful. It wasn’t safe. But it was *alive*.

And for the first time in years, Kael felt like he wasn’t just fighting the collapse.

He was building something new.

Outside, the sky cracked open. Rain fell—not water, but a fine mist of metallic vapor, a byproduct of the old air scrubbers. The mushrooms pulsed brighter. And somewhere, deep in the ruins, a child laughed. A sound so real, so uncorrupted, that Kael almost believed it had been born from the soil itself.

He closed his eyes. The PCR machine hummed. The light from the mushrooms danced across the floor. And for the first time in a long time, he didn’t fear the next generation.

He just waited. And listened.

“Maybe,” he said, “they were never meant to last. Maybe they were meant to *adapt*.”

He took the vial of insulin and placed it beside the PCR plate. Then he added a drop of the fungal extract—the one that had responded to the light. The reaction flared. The gel lit up in a soft blue-green. The bands were clean. Clear. Strong.

He didn’t know if it would grow. He didn’t know if it would survive the next generation. But for the first time, he didn’t feel the dread of failure. He felt something else—a quiet hope.

Later, as he sat in the dim light, the mushrooms began to grow faster. Not just on the tiles. On the walls. On the old lab bench. The glow spread like a slow tide, painting the bunker in shifting patterns of light. It wasn’t beautiful. It wasn’t safe. But it was *alive*.

And for the first time in years, Kael felt like he wasn’t just fighting the collapse.

He was building something new.

Outside, the sky cracked open. Rain fell—not water, but a fine mist of metallic vapor, a byproduct of the old air scrubbers. The mushrooms pulsed brighter. And somewhere, deep in the ruins, a child laughed. A sound so real, so uncorrupted, that Kael almost believed it had been born from the soil itself.

He closed his eyes. The PCR machine hummed. The light from the mushrooms danced across the floor. And for the first time in a long time, he didn’t fear the next generation.

He just waited. And listened.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The piece nails the prompt’s core requirements: a post-collapse biopunk lab, jury-rigged PCR, one-generation DNA, a black-market contract, and the bodily cost of untested mods. It even sneaks in the “unexpected upside” via the glowing mushrooms that stabilize reactions. World-building details—coffee-grinder centrifuge, smartphone thermistor, synth-clothing credits—are concrete and specific, giving the scene texture without drowning it.  

Yet the story never rises above a moody tableau. Kael is a pair of competent hands, not a person; we get no interior contradiction, no memory, no desire beyond “make the crop work.” Mira appears only to deliver exposition and trade goods, then vanishes. Their dialogue is purely transactional, devoid of subtext or tension. The stakes of the contract are stated, not felt: we’re told the northern settlement is desperate, but we neither see their hunger nor risk Kael’s reputation if he fails.  

The prose is serviceable but repetitive: “glow-in-the-dark mushrooms pulsed” appears three times in slightly different wording; “for the first time in months/years” is used four times, blunting any emotional crescendo. The final paragraph lunges for uplift—child’s laughter, metallic rain, mushrooms painting the bunker—without showing us why collapse has suddenly reversed into genesis. The transformation is asserted rather than dramatized; the story ends on a hopeful note it hasn’t earned.  

Sentence rhythm is generally smooth, but occasional clunkers (“The thing was a repurposed coffee grinder, its blades now coated in rust and biodegradable gel”) yank the reader out. The piece is coherent and on-prompt, but emotionally flat and unsurprising; every beat lands exactly where genre convention dictates.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment.

First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
I remember the wind howling through the pines like a voice trying to be heard. Not loud—just low, steady, as if the forest itself were breathing. It was the kind of night that settles in your bones, the kind that makes your thoughts feel thick and slow, like syrup poured over stone. I was sixteen, in the middle of a cold, unrelenting winter in northern Sweden. The village of Söderbäck had no name on any map I’d ever seen. It wasn’t on the bus routes, not on school timetables, not even in the local library. I’d only known it through Astrid’s stories, through her eyes, which were always wide, always watching.

We’d come here after my father’s job transfer—some bureaucratic shift in a paper mill that made us move from Stockholm to this place where the roads ended and the trees grew straight as soldiers. I didn’t want to come. I didn’t want to be here. But Astrid had said, “You’ll like it. It’s quiet. It’s real.” And so I did.

She’s the girl who lives in the old stone cottage by the lake, where the roof leaks in winter and the chimney always smokes even when no fire is lit. She says her grandmother taught her the old ways—*útiseta*, she calls it. “Sitting out,” she says, “to receive knowledge from beyond.” I didn’t believe her at first. Just a game. A prank. Something for teenagers to play with their fears. But she’s persistent. And I’m tired of pretending I don’t want to know what’s out there.

So tonight, we’re doing it.

We met at the edge of the forest at 11:45. The air was sharp, the kind of cold that doesn’t just chill your skin but makes your breath fog in slow, spiraling curls. Astrid wore her woolen coat over a black dress, her hair tied in a braid that didn’t quite stay in place. She carried a small iron ring with a cracked stone inside—“a key,” she said. “To open the door.”

“Why do we have to sit out?” I asked. “It’s just a burial mound. No one’s buried there.”

“Not just that,” she said, her voice calm, almost too calm. “It’s where the land remembers. Where the dead don’t sleep. They watch.”

She led me to the mound—a flat, rounded hill of black stone and moss, half-covered by snow. It looked ancient, like something carved from the earth itself. The stones were cold to the touch, and the moss pulsed faintly in the dim light of a single flashlight. Astrid didn’t light a candle. She just said, “No flame. No fire. The old ways don’t burn. They wait.”

We sat on the edge of the mound, facing the northern sky. The wind picked up, carrying with it a sound like distant voices, low and overlapping, like someone speaking in a language I didn’t know but somehow recognized. I didn’t feel afraid. Not at first. I felt… curious. Like I was being invited into something I’d never seen, something I’d only heard in books and old folk tales.

Astrid placed her hands flat on the stone. “Close your eyes,” she said. “Breathe in. Breathe out. Don’t think. Don’t speak. Just feel.”

I did. My breath fogged the air. The cold seeped into my bones. And then—something changed.

I felt a pressure behind my eyes. Like a weight pressing down from above. Not pain. Not discomfort. Just… presence. Like someone was watching from the dark. I opened my eyes slowly. The sky was still dark. The stars were visible, but they looked different—smaller, sharper, as if they’d been cut out and placed too close together. The wind had stopped.

Then, a whisper.

Not in my ears. In my mind. A voice, soft and layered, like wind through reeds. It said, *You are not alone.*

I gasped. Astrid didn’t flinch. She just looked at me, her face still calm, her eyes fixed on the horizon.

“It’s just the wind,” I said, though I didn’t believe it.

“No,” she replied. “It’s the mound. It remembers. It listens.”

I tried to focus on the words, the meaning. But the voice kept coming—faint, persistent. Not words, really. More like images: a girl in a white dress, standing by a frozen lake; a house with no windows; a door that never closes. I didn’t know where they came from. I didn’t know if they were real. But they were *there*, and they were *mine*.

Astrid didn’t speak again. She just sat, her hands still on the stone. I tried to close my eyes again, but the images kept returning—like memories I hadn’t lived. I saw myself standing at the edge of a lake, wearing a coat I didn’t own. I saw a classroom, full of faces I didn’t recognize. I saw a name—*Elin*—written in red on a chalkboard.

I looked at Astrid. She was staring at the ground, her fingers tracing the moss. “What did you see?” I asked.

She didn’t answer. Just smiled. “We don’t see what’s real,” she said. “We see what’s *meant* to be seen.”

The wind returned. The church bell rang—once—far away, at exactly midnight. I didn’t know if it was real. I didn’t know if it was part of the ritual. But it was there. And it made the air vibrate, like a string pulled too tight.

I wanted to leave. I wanted to run back to the cottage, to the warmth of the stove, to the sound of the radio playing pop songs. But I couldn’t move. My legs felt heavy. My mind was full of images that weren’t mine. I thought of Elin. I thought of the girl in the white dress. I thought of a door that never closes.

Was it real? I don’t know. Maybe it was just the cold. Maybe it was the isolation. Maybe it was the way Astrid had taught me to believe in things that didn’t exist. But I also didn’t want to forget it. I didn’t want to unsee it.

When the wind finally died and the silence returned, I opened my eyes. The stars were gone. The sky was dark. The mound stood still, silent. Astrid stood, slowly, and reached into her coat. She pulled out a small silver locket, its surface dull and cold.

“This,” she said, “was given to me by my grandmother. She said it would open when the wind stopped and the silence grew too thick.”

I didn’t ask what it held. I didn’t need to. I already knew.

We walked back slowly, the snow crunching under our boots. The village was quiet. The houses were dark. The church bell didn’t ring again. But I felt it—the echo of the whisper, the image of the girl in white, the name *Elin*. It stayed with me, like a memory I didn’t choose.

I don’t know if Útiseta worked. I don’t know if anything beyond the land ever answered. But I know this: I didn’t just sit out in the cold. I opened myself. And something—something ancient, or maybe just deep in me—responded.

And I didn’t know if I was the one who had learned something, or if I was the one who had been taught to believe it.  

The wind still howls at night. I still hear it. And sometimes, when I close my eyes, I see a girl in a white dress standing by a frozen lake.  

I don’t know if she’s real.  

But I know I didn’t see her for the first time tonight.  

I saw her because I let myself believe.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a solid attempt at folk-horror atmosphere, but it never fully commits to either the psychological or the supernatural reading the prompt demands. Linnea’s retrospective voice is consistent, yet it keeps the reader at arm’s length; we are told she is frightened, but the prose rarely transmits that fear to us. The ritual itself—útiseta—is described in generic terms: “close your eyes,” “breathe,” “feel.” These instructions could belong to a yoga class as easily as to a pagan rite, so the specificity promised in the prompt (“eerily specific traditional elements”) is missing. Astrid’s dialogue is functional but flat; she sounds like every other teen-witch stock character, delivering cryptic tag-lines instead of the unsettling mixture of adolescent bravado and inherited lore that would make her believable.  

The imagery is repetitive—wind, cold, stones, wind again—and the symbolic objects (iron ring, silver locket) appear without narrative payoff. The visions Linnea receives (girl in white, door that never closes, name on a chalkboard) are horror-shorthand, never woven back into her ordinary life or given enough detail to feel personally threatening. Because the stakes remain abstract, the climax—Linnea can’t move, hears a whisper—feels mild rather than terrifying. The final paragraph tries to retrofit significance (“I opened myself… something responded”), but the story has not dramatized any change in her that would make this claim persuasive. In short, the piece hovers politely on the threshold of dread without ever stepping inside.

She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. individual_results.model_response:
I remember the cold like it’s still in my bones. Not the kind that seeps through winter clothes or settles in the joints—no, this is deeper. It’s the kind that pools in your chest when you’re standing still, when the world goes quiet and the wind stops breathing. It’s midnight. The sky is a bruised grey, the kind of grey that doesn’t belong in northern Sweden in June, but here, in the village of Håll, it’s always been this way—mossy, heavy, like the earth is holding its breath.

I’m on the edge of the burial mound, bare feet pressed into the damp, peaty soil. The air smells of wet stone and something older—like old paper left in a cellar, or dried herbs left too long in a jar. Astrid stands a few paces behind me, her dark hair pulled back in a knot, her fingers wrapped around a small, carved wooden staff. She doesn’t say much. Just watches the mist curl around the stones like smoke from a forgotten fire.

“Don’t look down,” she says, voice low, almost a whisper. “Not until the wind stops.”

I don’t know why I agreed. I didn’t believe in any of this—no, not really. Not the way Astrid does. She talks about the mound like it’s a living thing, like it remembers things the world forgot. “It’s not a grave,” she says, over and over. “It’s a door. A memory gate. And when the wind stops, the door opens.”

I used to think she was just being dramatic. A little too into the dark side of things. But the last few weeks, the games we’ve played—Astrid’s “midnight games”—have started to feel real. We’ve sat in the woods, whispered names into the trees, made small offerings of sugar and salt to “wake the old roots.” We’ve tried to read the wind, to feel the pulse of the land. And every time, something shifts. A flicker in the leaves. A sound like a breath behind the trees. A moment when the silence feels too thick.

Tonight, it’s Útiseta. The “Outside Sitting.” A ritual she says her grandmother taught her, passed down in silence through generations. “It’s not about magic,” she told me. “It’s about listening. The dead don’t speak—they just *are*. And sometimes, they answer.”

I don’t believe in the dead. I believe in school exams, in homework, in the way my father’s new job in Luleå has made us all feel like strangers in a house we never built. But I’ve been sitting with Astrid for so long, watching her eyes light up when she talks about the stones, about the “knowledge” that waits in the dark, that I can’t pretend anymore.

We’ve prepared like we’re going to a concert. Astrid brought a bowl of cold water, a piece of dried birch bark, and a small iron ring she says “harmonizes the air.” I brought a notebook—my old one from Stockholm, with doodles of trains and city skylines. I didn’t know what to write. I didn’t know if I was supposed to write anything at all.

We sit on the edge of the mound, facing the open field. The mist is thick now, curling around the stones like a curtain. The wind stops. Not just a pause—it stops completely. The silence is so deep it feels like a physical thing, pressing against my ears. I feel my breath catch. Astrid doesn’t move. She just watches the mist, her fingers tracing the wood of the staff.

“Now,” she says. “Don’t move. Don’t speak. Just *be*.”

I don’t know what that means. But I do know that when she says it, I feel it—the shift. Like the world has tilted just slightly. The stones seem to glow under the moonlight, not with light, but with something else—something like memory. I see shadows that aren’t there. A shape, tall and thin, moving just beyond the edge of the mist. I blink. It’s gone.

Astrid doesn’t blink either. She just nods once, like she’s already seen it.

Then, from the edge of the field, a sound. Not a voice. A low hum, like a radio tuned to static, or the sound of a distant wind chime played too softly. It drifts through the air, slow and steady. I feel it in my teeth. My skin prickles. I want to turn, to ask what it is. But I don’t. I don’t move. I just sit, and listen.

The hum grows. Not louder—just more present. Like it’s weaving through the air, threading itself into the silence. And then, from somewhere deep beneath the mound, a sound like a breath. A slow, drawn-out exhale. Not human. Not animal. Something older.

I don’t know if it’s real. I don’t know if I’m imagining it. But my body is reacting. My hands are cold. My chest tightens. I can feel the pulse of the earth beneath me, like it’s breathing too.

Astrid doesn’t flinch. She just closes her eyes and whispers something I can’t hear. A name. A word. Maybe a prayer. Maybe just a memory.

The hum fades. The breath stops. The wind returns, just a little. And then, slowly, the mist begins to thin. The stones lose their glow. The silence returns, but it’s different now. Lighter. Like something has passed through.

We don’t speak. We don’t move. We just sit there, the two of us in the cold, the dark, the quiet.

After a long time—maybe ten minutes, maybe an hour—I open my eyes. The sky is still grey. The field is still empty. No one is there. No one has come.

But I can still feel it. The hum. The breath. The way the air has changed. Like the land has remembered something I didn’t know I was supposed to.

Astrid breaks the silence first. “Did you hear it?” she asks, voice quiet, almost too soft.

I nod. “I heard it.”

She smiles. A small, crooked thing. “That’s the point. You didn’t *see* it. You *felt* it. That’s how the knowledge comes.”

I don’t answer. I don’t know what to say. I don’t know if I believe in ghosts. I don’t know if I believe in the dead. But I know this: I’ve crossed a line. Not just with the ritual. With the trust. With the idea that something real—something ancient—could be listening.

I look at the mound again. The stones are still cold. The mist is gone. But I can still feel the hum in my bones. And I know, with a certainty that makes my skin crawl, that it wasn’t just the wind. It wasn’t just my imagination.

It was something else.

And it was watching us. Waiting. Listening.

I don’t know what it wants. I don’t know if it wants to be known. Or if it just wants to be heard.

But now, I know this: I will never forget the silence. And I will never forget the way the earth breathed beneath us.

And I will never forget that we didn’t just sit out on the mound.

We invited it in.

I used to think she was just being dramatic. A little too into the dark side of things. But the last few weeks, the games we’ve played—Astrid’s “midnight games”—have started to feel real. We’ve sat in the woods, whispered names into the trees, made small offerings of sugar and salt to “wake the old roots.” We’ve tried to read the wind, to feel the pulse of the land. And every time, something shifts. A flicker in the leaves. A sound like a breath behind the trees. A moment when the silence feels too thick.

Tonight, it’s Útiseta. The “Outside Sitting.” A ritual she says her grandmother taught her, passed down in silence through generations. “It’s not about magic,” she told me. “It’s about listening. The dead don’t speak—they just *are*. And sometimes, they answer.”

I don’t believe in the dead. I believe in school exams, in homework, in the way my father’s new job in Luleå has made us all feel like strangers in a house we never built. But I’ve been sitting with Astrid for so long, watching her eyes light up when she talks about the stones, about the “knowledge” that waits in the dark, that I can’t pretend anymore.

We’ve prepared like we’re going to a concert. Astrid brought a bowl of cold water, a piece of dried birch bark, and a small iron ring she says “harmonizes the air.” I brought a notebook—my old one from Stockholm, with doodles of trains and city skylines. I didn’t know what to write. I didn’t know if I was supposed to write anything at all.

We sit on the edge of the mound, facing the open field. The mist is thick now, curling around the stones like a curtain. The wind stops. Not just a pause—it stops completely. The silence is so deep it feels like a physical thing, pressing against my ears. I feel my breath catch. Astrid doesn’t move. She just watches the mist, her fingers tracing the wood of the staff.

“Now,” she says. “Don’t move. Don’t speak. Just *be*.”

I don’t know what that means. But I do know that when she says it, I feel it—the shift. Like the world has tilted just slightly. The stones seem to glow under the moonlight, not with light, but with something else—something like memory. I see shadows that aren’t there. A shape, tall and thin, moving just beyond the edge of the mist. I blink. It’s gone.

Astrid doesn’t blink either. She just nods once, like she’s already seen it.

Then, from the edge of the field, a sound. Not a voice. A low hum, like a radio tuned to static, or the sound of a distant wind chime played too softly. It drifts through the air, slow and steady. I feel it in my teeth. My skin prickles. I want to turn, to ask what it is. But I don’t. I don’t move. I just sit, and listen.

The hum grows. Not louder—just more present. Like it’s weaving through the air, threading itself into the silence. And then, from somewhere deep beneath the mound, a sound like a breath. A slow, drawn-out exhale. Not human. Not animal. Something older.

I don’t know if it’s real. I don’t know if I’m imagining it. But my body is reacting. My hands are cold. My chest tightens. I can feel the pulse of the earth beneath me, like it’s breathing too.

Astrid doesn’t flinch. She just closes her eyes and whispers something I can’t hear. A name. A word. Maybe a prayer. Maybe just a memory.

The hum fades. The breath stops. The wind returns, just a little. And then, slowly, the mist begins to thin. The stones lose their glow. The silence returns, but it’s different now. Lighter. Like something has passed through.

We don’t speak. We don’t move. We just sit there, the two of us in the cold, the dark, the quiet.

After a long time—maybe ten minutes, maybe an hour—I open my eyes. The sky is still grey. The field is still empty. No one is there. No one has come.

But I can still feel it. The hum. The breath. The way the air has changed. Like the land has remembered something I didn’t know I was supposed to.

Astrid breaks the silence first. “Did you hear it?” she asks, voice quiet, almost too soft.

I nod. “I heard it.”

She smiles. A small, crooked thing. “That’s the point. You didn’t *see* it. You *felt* it. That’s how the knowledge comes.”

I don’t answer. I don’t know what to say. I don’t know if I believe in ghosts. I don’t know if I believe in the dead. But I know this: I’ve crossed a line. Not just with the ritual. With the trust. With the idea that something real—something ancient—could be listening.

I look at the mound again. The stones are still cold. The mist is gone. But I can still feel the hum in my bones. And I know, with a certainty that makes my skin crawl, that it wasn’t just the wind. It wasn’t just my imagination.

It was something else.

And it was watching us. Waiting. Listening.

I don’t know what it wants. I don’t know if it wants to be known. Or if it just wants to be heard.

But now, I know this: I will never forget the silence. And I will never forget the way the earth breathed beneath us.

And I will never forget that we didn’t just sit out on the mound.

We invited it in.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a solid attempt at folk-horror atmosphere, but it never quite escapes the feeling of a carefully assembled checklist rather than a lived memory.  
Linnea’s first-person voice is consistent in diction, yet it is also monotonously ponderous; every observation is delivered at the same weighty register, so the prose fatigues rather than terrifies.  
The ritual instructions (“Don’t look down until the wind stops”) are evocative, but Astrid’s dialogue is limited to a handful of oracular sentences that give her no interiority; she functions as a plot-device crone in teenage skin.  
Because we never see Linnea’s scepticism in action—only hear her assert it in past-tense summary—the moment of belief (“I’ve crossed a line”) feels declared, not dramatised.  
The sensory imagery is repetitive: “cold like it’s still in my bones” appears in the first sentence and is then paraphrased four more times; the hum, the breath, the mist, and the stones glow and un-glow in a loop that blurs rather than sharpens.  
Ambiguity is handled too cautiously: every potentially supernatural cue is immediately echoed by Linnea’s internal commentary (“I don’t know if it’s real…”), so the reader is never granted the genuine vertigo of uncertainty.  
The ending line, “We invited it in,” wants to land as a chilling revelation, but because the story has already told us several times that something responded, the inversion feels pre-packaged.  
On the mechanical side, the piece stays within the 1000-word window, keeps to first-person past, and situates itself in the requested time and place, so instruction-adherence is high; stylistically, however, it leans on abstract nouns (“memory,” “knowledge,” “silence”) instead of concrete detail, and the sentence rhythm is persistently adjectival, producing a purple tinge without achieving poetic precision.  
In short: competent scaffolding, thin skin.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment.

First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
Wind occasionally rustles the pine trees, sounding almost like faint whispers. I can still hear it now—soft, insistent, like the breath of something old and patient. It’s the kind of wind that doesn’t blow from one direction but seems to come from everywhere at once, curling around the edges of the world like smoke. That’s how I remember it: the wind on the night of Útiseta.

I was seventeen, though I never felt that age. I felt like a stranger in my own skin, like I’d been dropped into a story that didn’t belong to me. My father’s job had moved him from Stockholm to a small village in northern Sweden—Tågby, they called it. A place where the roads were long and the silence thick as moss. The houses were built of stone and wood, leaning slightly into the cold, and the air always carried that sharp, clean scent of snowmelt and pine resin. I didn’t know how to adjust. I didn’t know how to be still.

Astrid found me at the school gate the first week. She had dark hair pulled into a messy braid, eyes sharp and bright, and she didn’t smile when she spoke. “You’re new,” she said. “You’ll like this place. It’s not like Stockholm. Nothing ever happens here. Not really.” She said it like it was a secret, like it was a kind of truth.

We became friends over shared silence. Over the way we both hated the way people in school pretended to know everything. Over the way we both felt like we were missing something—something buried beneath the surface of everyday life.

Then she started talking about the rituals.

At first, it was just jokes. “Midnight games,” she’d say, grinning. “You know how kids play pranks? Well, we do something older. Something real.” She didn’t explain, didn’t need to. She just showed me the stones. The burial mound near the old church, half-covered in lichen, shaped like a sleeping wolf. “It’s not just a grave,” she said. “It’s a door.”

I didn’t believe her. I thought she was joking. Or that she was just trying to be cool. But then she started teaching me. How to sit still. How to breathe in through the nose, out through the mouth, counting each breath. How to wear wool socks, even in summer. How to avoid looking at the sky directly. How to keep your hands folded over your lap, palms up.

“Útiseta,” she said. “We sit out on the mound at midnight. We don’t speak. We don’t move. We just wait. And sometimes—sometimes—we hear things.”

I didn’t ask what kind of things. I didn’t want to know. I just wanted to go.

That night, the sky was clear. The stars were sharp and cold, like needles. The wind had picked up, and the trees shivered, their branches scraping against each other like fingers. I wore my woolen coat, even though it was only early autumn. Astrid had insisted on it—“It keeps the cold from the inside,” she said. “And it keeps the spirits from coming in.”

We walked in silence. The path was narrow, winding through frozen grass and fallen birch. The air smelled of damp earth and something older—something like old paper or burnt herbs. I kept glancing at Astrid. She didn’t look nervous. She looked calm. Like she knew what she was doing. Like she’d done this a hundred times.

We reached the mound at 11:45. It was shaped like a small hill, worn smooth by centuries of snow and wind. The stones were cold and slick. Astrid didn’t touch them. She just knelt, placed her hands flat on the ground, and said, “We are not here to ask. We are here to receive.”

I didn’t understand. I didn’t want to. But I didn’t say no either.

She handed me a small piece of dried juniper, wrapped in cloth. “Smell it,” she said. “It’s not for you. It’s for the mound.”

I did. The smell was sharp, medicinal, like smoke and memory.

We sat in a circle, back to back. The wind picked up again, louder now. I felt it in my bones. I could hear it in my teeth. And then—something else.

A low hum. Not from the wind. From beneath the earth. Like a pulse. Like the ground was breathing.

Astrid didn’t flinch. “That’s the mound,” she said. “It’s waking.”

I stared at her. “You’re not serious.”

She looked at me. “I’m serious. I’ve done this before. I’ve sat here. I’ve waited. And sometimes—sometimes—someone speaks.”

I didn’t believe her. But I didn’t want to move. The cold seeped into my clothes. The stars above seemed to move slower, like they were watching us. I felt my breath catch. My hands trembled.

Then, just after midnight, the hum deepened. The wind stopped. The trees fell silent.

And I heard it.

Not a voice. Not a word. But a sound—like a child laughing, but not from this world. Like something remembering a name.

I looked at Astrid. She wasn’t moving. Her eyes were closed. Her fingers were pressed into the earth. I didn’t know if she was listening or if she was just waiting. I didn’t know if I was supposed to.

I opened my mouth to speak. But no sound came out.

Then, a whisper—so soft, so close—it seemed to come from the stones themselves. “*Linnea*,” it said.

I froze.

Astrid didn’t move. She didn’t open her eyes. “It’s not a name,” she said, quietly. “It’s a memory. A name from long ago. One of the ones we’ve forgotten.”

I tried to speak. I tried to say I didn’t believe it. But my voice was gone. My body felt heavy. The cold wasn’t just in the air anymore—it was in my blood.

The whisper came again. “*You were here before.*”

I thought I saw a shadow move behind the mound. Not a person. Not a thing. Just a shape, like smoke, like a memory given form.

Astrid didn’t react. She just sat there, still as stone. “We don’t control it,” she said. “We don’t ask. We just let it come. And sometimes—sometimes—it remembers us.”

I didn’t know what to do. I didn’t know if I had been tricked. If the wind had been lying. If the stones had been speaking in my head.

When I finally stood up, the ground felt different. The wind had returned, but it sounded like it was carrying something else now—like it was full of voices, overlapping, not speaking but humming, like a song no one had ever heard.

Astrid stood too. “We’re done,” she said. “Now go home. Don’t tell anyone.”

I didn’t say anything. I just walked back. The path was long. The silence felt heavier than before.

That night, I dreamed of the mound. Of the wind. Of a girl sitting there, watching me, not with eyes, but with the shape of a memory.

I don’t know if the voices were real. I don’t know if Útiseta ever worked. But I know this: I sat there. I listened. And I felt something—something that wasn’t mine.

Now, when the wind rustles the pines, I sometimes think I hear it too. Not a word. Not a name. But a breath. A pulse. A slow, ancient rhythm.

And I wonder—was it the wind? Or was it just me remembering?  

Or was it something that had been waiting for me all along?

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The piece is a solid first draft that hits most of the prompt’s beats: rural 1990s Sweden, two teenage girls, a burial-mound vigil, mounting ambiguity about the supernatural, and a retrospective frame. It is readable, atmospheric, and keeps the required 1 000-word neighborhood.  

However, it never rises above competent. The narrator’s voice is monotonous: long, declarative sentences stacked end-to-end produce a droning effect that flattens both dread and character. Description is repetitive (“the wind… like smoke” appears twice; “cold… in my blood / in my bones / in the air” is hammered until numb). Astrid is a plot device rather than a person: we get no gesture, tic, or private moment that would make her persuasive as either manipulator or friend. Dialogue is mostly expository rule-recitation (“We don’t control it… We don’t ask…”) and therefore feels wooden and “tell-don’t-show.”  

The central ritual is under-imagined. We are told about juniper, wool socks, and palm-up posture, but the sensory payoff is a generic “low hum” and a disembodied whisper of the protagonist’s name—scares that feel mailed-in rather than earned. The ambiguity the prompt demands wobbles: the narrator immediately interprets every phenomenon (“It’s waking,” “It’s a memory”), stripping the reader of the pleasure of deciding what is real.  

Structurally, the piece is front-loaded with flashback and back-story; the night on the mound starts two-thirds of the way through, so the escalation feels rushed and the denouement merely repeats the uncertainty already stated. The final paragraph tries for a circular echo but simply restates earlier motifs without deepening them, producing an ending that is neither surprising nor cathartic.  

Stylistically, the prose is serviceable but cliché-ridden (“sharp as needles,” “stranger in my own skin,” “like fingers scraping”). There is no sentence-level music, no rhythmic variation, no startling image that makes the reader pause. At no point does the language itself become an instrument of dread; it merely reports that dread occurred.  

In sum, the story fulfills the assignment but does so mechanically, without psychological precision, linguistic freshness, or genuine fright. It is not amateurish in the sense of being illiterate, but it is generic: any Scandinavian setting and any teen narrator could be swapped in without changing the effect.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The saxophone wails — a long, mournful note that cuts through the humid New Orleans air like a blade. I’m standing in the middle of a sidewalk that looks like it’s been painted with spilled neon, surrounded by people who move like they’ve got secrets in their pockets and are too tired to share them. My hands are still shaking from the ride, from the cold, from the way my mom’s voice still echoes in my head: *“Taylor, you’re not going to survive this.”* I didn’t survive the last time I tried to survive. I didn’t survive the last time I was told I wasn’t enough. Not for my family. Not for the world.  

I’m not supposed to be here. I’m supposed to be in Tennessee, in a house with a porch swing that creaks like a dying animal, where everyone knows my name and assumes I’m just a kid who’s been through too much. But I’m not. I’m not any of that. I’m a person who finally stopped pretending. And I’m here, in this city that smells like fried food and wet pavement and something older — something like memory.  

I’m walking, slowly, trying to breathe. My phone is dead. My clothes are too big, too old — the kind of clothes that used to belong to someone else, someone who didn’t know how to wear them right. I keep looking around, like I’m waiting for someone to say, *“You’re not supposed to be here.”* But no one does. No one even looks at me like I’m a threat.  

Then I see her.  

A girl with a frayed denim jacket and a black backpack that looks like it’s been through a war. She’s sitting on a curb, hunched over, playing a guitar with one hand, humming something that sounds like a lullaby but is really a scream. Her hair is tangled, and she’s not looking at anyone. I don’t know if she’s sad or angry or just really tired.  

I sit down across from her. “You okay?” I ask.  

She doesn’t look up. “I’m not okay,” she says, and her voice is soft, like it’s been scraped raw. “I just don’t know where I’m going anymore.”  

I swallow. “Me neither.”  

She finally looks at me. Her eyes are dark, like storm clouds. “You look like you’ve been running.”  

I nod. “I have.”  

She smiles — not a real smile, more like a crack in the ice. “You know, I used to think running was the only way to be free.” She pauses. “Now I think it’s just the beginning of something worse.”  

I don’t know what to say. I want to say, *I know*, but I don’t. I don’t know what I know. I just know that I feel like I’ve been standing at the edge of a cliff for years and now I’ve finally stepped off. And I don’t know if I’m going to fall or if I’ll land in something better.  

We sit in silence for a while. The saxophone plays again — a little higher now, like it’s trying to find a new tone. The city moves around us, people talking, laughing, walking with purpose. I watch a couple pass by, holding hands, and I feel something sharp in my chest — not jealousy, not envy. Just pain. Because I remember what it felt like to be invisible. To be told you weren’t *real*. To be told your body wasn’t yours.  

“You ever think about staying?” I ask her.  

She looks at me like I’ve just said something dangerous. “Stay? In New Orleans? You don’t even know what it’s like here.”  

“I know what it’s like to be afraid,” I say. “I know what it’s like to not belong.”  

She exhales. “Then maybe you don’t need to run. Maybe you just need to stop pretending you can.”  

I don’t know what to say to that. I don’t know if I believe it. But for the first time in days, I don’t feel like I’m alone.  

Later, we walk to a small park near the river. The air is thick with the smell of jasmine and wet grass. There’s a bench, and we sit on it, watching kids play tag, laughing, running. I don’t feel like I’m watching a performance anymore. I feel like I’m just… here.  

“You ever think about going back?” she asks.  

I shake my head. “No. I don’t think I ever will.”  

She nods. “Then maybe this is where you start.”  

I look at her. “What if I don’t want to start?”  

She smiles again — small, quiet. “Then you don’t have to. You just have to be here. Right now. With someone who doesn’t know the whole story, but still sees you.”  

I don’t know if that’s true. I don’t know if anyone sees me. But for the first time in a long time, I don’t feel like I’m hiding.  

The saxophone plays one last note — soft, fading. I close my eyes.  

Maybe I don’t need to survive. Maybe I just need to live.  

And maybe, just maybe, I can do that here.  

With someone who doesn’t know me — and that’s okay.  

Because maybe that’s what freedom really feels like. Not running away. Not escaping. Just… showing up.  

Even when you don’t know who you are.  

Even when you don’t know if you’ll survive.  

Even when you’re just a kid with a dead phone and a heart that’s still learning how to beat.  

And that’s enough.  

For now.  

That’s all I need.  

I open my eyes. The city is still loud. The saxophone is still playing. But I’m not afraid anymore.  

I’m just here.  

And that’s more than I’ve ever had.  

And maybe that’s all I’ll ever need.  

I reach into my pocket and pull out a crumpled piece of paper — a note from the school counselor. *“Concerning behavioural patterns.”*  

I crumple it again.  

And I let it fall into the grass.  

Because I’m not a problem.  

I’m not a mistake.  

I’m just a person.  

And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.  

The saxophone stops.  

And for the first time in days, I don’t feel like I’m running.  

I feel like I’m finally… walking.  

And that’s where I want to be.  

And that’s where I’m going.  

Even if I don’t know where it leads.  

Even if I don’t know if I’ll make it.  

Because I’m not running anymore.  

I’m just… here.  

And that’s all I ever wanted.  

And that’s all I’ll ever need.  

The city hums around me.  

And I breathe.  

And I keep walking.  

With the girl who doesn’t know my name.  

And maybe, just maybe, that’s enough.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the prompt’s basic requirements—Taylor is a 16-year-old trans runaway, now alone in New Orleans, meeting another runaway, written in first-person with internal monologue—but it does so in the most generic, repetitive, self-congratulatory way possible.  
Taylor’s voice starts with a little vinegar (“mind-fuckingly bored,” “stupid smug school counsellor”) then instantly collapses into the same soft-focus, fortune-cookie uplift that dominates the rest of the chapter. The diction loops: “I don’t know what to say,” “I don’t know if I believe it,” “maybe that’s enough,” “maybe that’s all I’ll ever need,” until the reader is drowning in maybe. Every beat is restated three times; the saxophone is summoned three times to do the same emotional lifting. Nothing actually happens: two kids sit, exchange one-sentence backstories, trade Hallmark cards (“You just have to be here. Right now. With someone who… still sees you”), then decide that merely existing equals freedom. The city is sketched in three adjectives apiece—“fried food and wet pavement and something older”—and never acquires any specific danger, texture, or surprise. The other runaway is a prop: no name, no history, no agenda, no menace, no chemistry; her only function is to assure Taylor that running away is actually a spiritual win. The dialogue is 100 % therapy-speak, stripped of age, region, race, class, or trans-culture markers; no one sounds 16, or human.  
The emotional arc is a straight, unearned escalator: from “I’m terrified” to “I’m finally walking” in a single afternoon, with no concrete obstacle, no betrayal, no hunger, no cop, no transphobic remark, no offer of cash or sex or shelter—nothing at all to test Taylor’s resolve. The crumpled counselor’s note is the single visual action in 1 000 words, and even that is underlined with a triumphant internal press release (“I’m not a problem. I’m not a mistake.”) that tells us exactly how to feel.  
Stylistically the piece is overwrought but empty: every sentence reaches for poetic height yet lands in cliché (“eyes like storm clouds,” “city hums around me,” “heart still learning how to beat”). The tense shifts promised in the prompt appear once or twice then vanish; the voice flattens into a monotone of uplift. Paragraphs end on the same anaphoric uplift beat, killing narrative momentum. The whole chapter feels like a catharsis memo to the author, not a story sent out to readers.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter 2: The City That Doesn’t Know How to Hold You**

I don’t know how I got here. One second I was on the cracked sidewalk of a backroad in rural Tennessee, the next I was on a cracked sidewalk in New Orleans—*New Orleans*—with a stranger’s backpack on my shoulders and a phone that’s been dead for twenty minutes.  

My phone battery is at 12%. I don’t know where the charger is. I don’t know if I’ll ever get it back. I don’t know if I even *want* to.  

I’m sitting on a bench under a streetlamp that flickers like a dying candle. The air smells like wet asphalt, fried food, and something vaguely sweet—maybe gumbo? I don’t know. I don’t care. I just want to not feel like a ghost. Like I’ve been erased from the world.  

I’m not supposed to be here. I didn’t plan this. I didn’t *ask* to be dropped into a city that’s loud, humid, and full of people who don’t even know how to look at you without judging.  

*You’re not a problem*, I keep telling myself. *You’re not a mess. You’re not a risk.*  

But the truth is, I am all of those things. And I’ve been trying to be invisible since I told my mom I’m trans. I told her two days ago. I didn’t know if she’d cry. I didn’t know if she’d laugh. I didn’t know if she’d just *stop* breathing.  

She didn’t. She just said, “You’re not *really* going to do this, are you?” like I was some kind of prank. Like I’d just pulled a trick on her. Like I’d forgotten I was her kid.  

And then she hung up.  

I didn’t cry. I didn’t scream. I just walked out. I walked to the bus stop. I walked to the edge of town. I walked until I couldn’t walk anymore.  

And then I just *left*.  

Now I’m in New Orleans. I’m in a city where the streets are full of music and the air smells like time. And I don’t know if I can survive it.  

I see a kid sitting on a rusted fire escape across the street. A girl, maybe sixteen. Wearing a hoodie that says *I AM NOT A MIRROR*, and her eyes are red. She’s holding a sketchbook.  

She looks up.  

“Hey,” she says. “You lost?”  

I don’t answer. I don’t know how to.  

She leans forward. “You look like you’ve seen a ghost.”  

I blink. “I don’t know what that means.”  

“Yeah,” she says, “you do. You look like you’ve just been kicked out of a family dinner. And you’re not even sure if you’re supposed to be sad or angry.”  

I swallow. My chest tightens. “I don’t know. I just… I just don’t know how to be here.”  

She closes her sketchbook. “I know. I used to think I was the only one.”  

“You’re not?”  

“No. I’ve been running for two weeks. From my mom. From the school. From the thing they said about me—‘you’re not a real girl.’ I didn’t know what that meant. Until I saw the way they looked at me in the mirror. Like I was a mistake.”  

I stare at her. “That’s not what I was told.”  

She laughs, dry and broken. “No. But it’s the same thing. You just don’t get it until you’re on the run.”  

I look down at my hands. They’re shaking. I don’t know why.  

“You’re not alone,” she says. “I don’t know where I’m going. I don’t know if I’ll ever find a place where I can just… be.”  

I nod. “Me neither.”  

We sit in silence. The city hums around us—street vendors, a saxophone playing somewhere, a dog barking. The air is thick with possibility. And fear.  

I don’t know if I can trust her. I don’t know if I can trust anyone. But I can’t keep sitting here. I need to move.  

“Do you have a place to stay?” I ask.  

She shakes her head. “I found a shelter downtown. They take runaways. But it’s full. I was told to come in at 7 a.m. I didn’t.”  

“Why not?”  

She looks at me. “Because I don’t want to be *seen*. I don’t want to be *known*. I don’t know if I can handle it.”  

I feel something shift inside me. Not hope. Not exactly. But something like *recognition*. Like I’ve been standing in the dark for too long, and now someone else is standing there too.  

We walk together to the corner. I don’t say much. I just follow.  

The city is overwhelming. The colors are too bright. The people are too loud. The music is too real.  

We pass a bakery. A sign says *Saffron & Spice*. I don’t know what it means. I don’t care.  

“Do you like food?” she asks.  

I hesitate. “I don’t know. I haven’t eaten since yesterday.”  

She grins. “Then come in. I’ve got a coupon for free pancakes.”  

I laugh. It’s a real laugh. Not forced. Not fake. Just *me*.  

We walk in. The place is warm. The smell of syrup and cinnamon fills the air. A man in a chef’s coat hands me a plate. “Free for the night,” he says. “You’re not a problem.”  

I stare at the pancakes. They look like they were made by someone who loves life.  

I take a bite. It’s sweet. It’s warm. It’s real.  

I don’t cry. I don’t say anything. But I feel something open. Like a door that wasn’t there before.  

Later, she tells me her name is Mira. She’s from Memphis. She used to go to the same school as me. She didn’t come out. She just… stopped.  

She says, “I think I’m not supposed to be here. I think I’m supposed to be in a place where I can just be.”  

I look at her. “I think I’m not supposed to be here either.”  

She smiles. “Then maybe we’re both just trying to survive.”  

I don’t know if I’ll stay. I don’t know if I’ll ever feel safe. But for the first time in two days, I don’t feel like I’m running from something.  

I feel like I’m *here*.  

And that’s something.  

Even if the city doesn’t know how to hold me, maybe I can learn how to hold myself.  

Maybe that’s enough.  

I look at my phone. 12%. Still dead.  

I don’t care.  

I just press my hands over my chest and breathe.  

And for the first time in a long time, I don’t feel like a ghost.  

I feel like a person.  

And that’s enough.  

For now.  

---  
*Word count: 998*

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The chapter delivers a first-person, present-tense account of Taylor’s first day in New Orleans, exactly as requested. It keeps the internal monologue front-and-center, introduces another runaway (Mira), and stays within the YA-drama register. Word count is 998, under the 1000-word cap.

Strengths  
- Voice: Taylor’s diction is convincingly teen—self-aware, sarcastic, raw, occasionally poetic without sounding adult.  
- Emotional stakes: The trans-coming-out wound is kept alive; every observation loops back to “Do I get to exist?”  
- Atmosphere: New Orleans is sketched quickly but with sensory detail (wet asphalt, saxophone, syrup-and-cinnamon).  
- Pacing: A single day, a single arc—bench → meet Mira → pancake house → tentative hope. No subplot sprawl.

Weaknesses  
- Repetition: The “I don’t know how to be here / I don’t know if I can survive it” refrain appears in four near-identical iterations; each weakens the last.  
- Dialogue: Mira’s lines function as exposition delivery devices (“I’ve been running for two weeks…”) rather than speech. Their first exchange is a therapy session, not a street-corner negotiation between two guarded kids.  
- Show/tell imbalance: We are told Taylor feels “something shift inside me,” “I feel like a person,” etc. The pancake moment is supposed to be the hinge, but we get only one bite of sensory detail before the narrator explains the epiphany.  
- Mira’s opacity: We learn nothing about how she eats, where she sleeps, how she scans for danger, or why she trusts Taylor instantly; she exists to mirror Taylor’s pain rather than to feel like a separate consciousness.  
- Ending uplift: The final paragraphs lurch toward catharsis (“I don’t feel like a ghost… I feel like a person”) without a concrete external trigger beyond free pancakes and a stranger’s smile. The transformation feels rushed for a kid who was “pure disaster” hours earlier.  
- Prose micro-stumbles: “The air smells like time” is abstract; “pancakes look like they were made by someone who loves life” is cliché; “I just press my hands over my chest and breathe” edges on self-help brochure.  
- Missing danger: The prompt stresses “not knowing what the dangers are.” Aside from a flickering streetlamp and a dead phone, the city is benevolent: free food, instant ally, no cops, no predators, no trans-phobic micro-aggressions. The tension leaks out.

Technical notes  
Tense mixing is present but purposeful (“I don’t know how I got here” vs. “Now I’m in New Orleans”) and fits the prompt’s “mixed tense” allowance. Grammar is clean; punctuation is competent.

Overall  
A solid scaffold that hits the assignment’s checkboxes, but the emotional arc is accelerated, the secondary character is thin, and the prose slips into explanatory summary just when scene-work is most needed. It reads like a strong first-draft chapter rather than a polished piece.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping. Off my shoulder. Like it’s mocking me. Like it knows I’m trying to be strong, like I’m trying to *not* look like a kid who just got kicked out of a small-town church basement by a family that still thinks gender is a costume. New Orleans. *New Orleans*. I didn’t even know the city had a name. Just a blur of red-brick buildings, a smell like fried onions and wet pavement, and the sound of a saxophone that sounded like it was crying. I’m not supposed to be here. I’m not supposed to *exist* like this.

I’m standing in front of a corner store with a neon sign that says “Papa’s Pantry” and a sign above the door that says “No Trespassing – Unauthorized Entry Results in Immediate Arrest.” I don’t know if that’s true. I just know I’m not supposed to be here. I’m not supposed to be *anywhere*.

My hands are shaking. Not from cold. From fear. From the way my chest feels like it’s full of static. I didn’t run for freedom. I ran because I didn’t want to be seen. I didn’t want to be *known*. I didn’t want to be the one who said, “I’m a girl,” and then had to explain it like it was a crime. Mom said, “You’re just being dramatic.” Dad said, “You’ll grow out of it.” The school counselor said, “Concerning behavioural patterns.” Like I’m a case study. Like I’m a warning label.

I didn’t want to be a warning label. I just wanted to breathe.

I take a deep breath and push open the door. The bell jingles like a knife. The air is thick with the smell of fried chicken and something sweet—cinnamon? Sugar? The cashier is a woman in a floral apron, her hair in a bun like a schoolteacher’s. She looks up from the register and says, “You okay, honey?”

I nod. “Yeah. Just… new here.”

She smiles. “First time?”

I don’t answer. I can’t. My voice is stuck in my throat. I just want to disappear.

She hands me a paper cup of coffee. “Free. For the road. You look like you’ve been running.”

I take it. It’s hot. I don’t drink it. I just hold it like a weapon.

Then I see her. A girl sitting on a stool by the window, her legs crossed, a book open, her hair in a messy braid. She looks up. Her eyes are dark, like storm clouds. She doesn’t smile. She doesn’t blink. She just stares.

“You’re not supposed to be here,” she says, without looking up.

I don’t know how to respond. “I’m not.”

She finally looks at me. “You’re not supposed to be anywhere.”

I freeze. The words hit me like a slap. It’s not a question. It’s a truth.

She sets her book down. “I’m Lila. I’ve been running for two months.”

I don’t know what to say. I just stare at her. My backpack slips again. I grab it. It feels like it’s pulling me back into the past.

“You know,” she says, “I used to think running meant freedom. Now I think it means loneliness. Like you’re just… moving from one cage to another.”

I nod. My voice is barely a whisper. “I don’t know what I’m doing.”

“You don’t have to,” she says. “Just breathe. And don’t look at the sky too much. It watches you.”

I look up. The sky is a bruised purple. The sun is just setting. It feels heavy. Like the world is full of secrets and I’m standing in the middle of them.

We sit in silence for a while. The coffee cools. I don’t drink it. I just watch her. She’s not like the other kids I’ve seen. She doesn’t try to be nice. She doesn’t try to fix anything. She just *is*. Like she knows things I don’t.

Then she says, “You said you came out. To your family?”

I don’t answer right away. My heart pounds. I don’t want to talk about it. I don’t want to relive it. But I can’t lie.

“I did. I didn’t know how to tell them. I thought if I just… disappeared, they’d stop asking.”

Lila leans forward. “That’s not how it works. You don’t disappear. You show up. In a new place. With a new name. A new face.”

I blink. “You think I can do that?”

She looks at me like I’m a puzzle she’s trying to solve. “You already did. You just didn’t know it.”

I don’t know what to say. I just feel the weight of everything—my fear, my hope, my confusion. I want to cry. I want to run. I want to vanish again.

But then I see something. A flyer taped to the window. “Free Food & Shelter – The New Orleans Youth Collective. Open 6 PM to 10 PM. No questions asked.”

I look at Lila. “Do you know about that?”

She nods. “I go there. Every week. It’s not safe. But it’s real. It’s not a lie.”

I hesitate. I don’t want to go. I don’t want to trust anyone. But something in me—something small, fragile—wants to try.

“Can I go?” I ask.

She smiles. A real one. “Only if you promise not to run again.”

I laugh. It’s shaky. “I don’t know if I can promise that.”

“You don’t have to,” she says. “Just show up. And breathe. And maybe—just maybe—find someone who sees you.”

I don’t know if I believe her. But I don’t know if I can live without trying.

I stand up. The strap on my backpack slips again. I grab it. This time, I don’t flinch.

“Thanks,” I say.

She doesn’t answer. She just watches me go. Like she’s watching a storm break.

And for the first time in days, I feel… light. Not safe. Not free. But *alive*. Like I’m finally not just hiding. I’m here. I’m real. And maybe, just maybe, I’m not alone.

The sky is dark now. The city hums. I walk down the street, not looking back. I don’t know where I’m going. I just know I’m not running anymore.

I’m walking. And that’s enough.
